JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 17.

PHYSICS KING AT THE '15 FEED
Dr. Ames'Popular Course Has Its Funny
Side—Freshmen Dine on Sly at
Maryland Country Club.

Physics was immortalized Mon(lay night at the junior class banquet at the Rennert.
Although there were only seven
set speeches, every member of the
class present "had something to
say.," and in respect to speech-making, the banquet was one of . the
most novel and interesting in the
history of Hopkins "feeds."
At the same time the juniors
were dining, sixty members of the
freshman class were sitting around
the board at the Maryland Country
Club. They had planned and carried off the affair in the utmost
secrecy, and for this reason were
able to spirit away the president of
the sophomore class, handcuffed
and in an automobile.
When his classmen learned of
this capture a handful rushed to
the club, but were not strong
enough in numbers to make any
concerted impression. One injured
freshman (black .eye), however,
was punished for his audacity, but
after a few minutes' chase over
the snowy fields in the vicinity of
the club, the sophomores got away.
The junior banquet was attended
by the spirits of W. H. Anderson
and "Billy" Sunday.
The menu was in the form of an
experiment, and the little book was
called "A Manual of Physics." The
cover, like the well known Ames
and Bliss volume, was of dark blue
.with printing in gold. A cut of the
Physics Laboratory adorned the
cover, and on the dome of the
building were the figures "1915,"
sending out rays of light in sunburst style.
The experiment, set in exact typographical imitation of its parent
volume, was:

EXPERIMENT I.
(A class of observers is required.)
Object: To verify Fletcher's theory
of mastication and to determine the coefficient of satisfaction at a class banquet.
General theory: Fletcher's theory of
mastication is derived from the f011owing hypotheses:
I. That food should be thoroughly
chewed.
2. That by chewing thoroughly,
greater nutriment may be derived from
the given amount of food.
3. That the amount of nutriment will
be directly proportional to the amount
of chewing.
From these rules Fletcher laid down
the formula:
Number of chews
= Nutriment.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 24, 1914.

DR. GOODNOW NEW HOPKINS PRESIDENT
Eton Professor of Political Science of Columbia University, and the
Present Constitutional Adviser to the Chinese Republic,
Chosen Six Weeks Ago—Official Announcement
at the Commemoration Day Exercises.
Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow, at
present the constitutional adviser to
the Chinese Republic, and one of
the foremost political scientists of
this country, will be the next president of the Johns Hopkins University.
The announcement that the Columbia University professor had
been selected by the trustees was
made yesterday by President Keyser, of the trustees, at the Commemoration Day exercises.
Dr. Goodnow succeeds Dr. Ira
Remsen, whose resignation from
the presidency was accepted on
April 21, 1911. In the interregnum
an administrative committee, headed by Dr. William H. Welch, had
acted as executive.
The selection of Dr. Goodnow
has delighted every friend of the
University. When the•trustees met
to consider the selection of a president, two alternatives were offered
which presented a difficult situation to solve. A man noted. for
scholarly attainments was desired
by some of :the trustees, while
others wanted a business man, one
whose chief service would be to collect funds and handle the details of
moving the University to its new
buildings on the Homewood estate.
After a consideration of the many
names, suggested, the trustees finally
agreed upon Dr. Goodnow as preeminently qualified to fill the presidency. He combined the two types
of man they were seeking. They
knew him to be one.of the foremost
of American educators, one of its
authorities on political science, and
he possessed eminent qualities of
business and organilation. For
these latter attributes he was selected to serve as adviser to the
new Chinese Republic.
The only obstacle that Stood in
the way of the Selection' of Dr.
Goodnow was the three-year contract he had made with China. This
did not balk the trustees, however,
for they had determined to secure
him. Dr. Goodnow was called, and
shortly after sent a reply :that he
would accept if he could be released
from his contract. The appearance
in Peking, China, of William W.
Rockhill, former American ambassador to Turkey, was followed immediately by the announcement that
President Yuan Shi-Kai of China
would gladly release Dr. Goodnow

The thirty-eighth anniversary of
the founding of Johns Hopkins,
celebrated Monday morning in McCoy Hall, was notable because of
the official announcement of the
selection of the University's third
president, Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow.
There, were, however, other features, which, had they not been overshadowed by the interest in R.
Brent Keyser's speech, would have
made the Commemoration Day exercises the most impressive in the
memory of present students of the
University.
Dr. Andrew Jackson Montague,
congressman from Virginia, and
former governor of his State, delivered a scholarly political oration
in which he said that President
Wilson owed his career to his Hopkins training.
A remarkably striking portrait of
Dean Edward H. Griffin, in academic gown, seated at his desk, was
presented to the University by the
Alumni Association.
W. Calvin Chesnut, a member of
the Baltimore bar, who was one of
the first to study under Dean Griffin when he came to Hopkins 25
years ago, delivered the presentation address.
Dr. Welch accepted the painting,
and looking around for Dean Griffin, finally located him in a corner
of the platform. The Dean arose in
response to the tribute that was
paid him, and the faculty and audience stood in his honor. The
portrait will be hung in McCoy'
Hall this week.

Dr. Montague's Address.

Dr. Andrew Jackson Montague,
the chief orator, had no fixed subject, but his theme dealt with the
political changes and advances since
the time of the framing of the Constitution of the United States.
As an introduction, the speaker,
who is a trustee of the Carnegie
Peace Foundation, congratulated
the University upon the selection of
Dr. Goodnow as its next president.
Then he began his address, a comparison of the social and economic
conditions of Washington's day to
our oWn:

being, we had founded a limited
monarchy, based upon the theory of

A. K. BARTON RESIGNS AS EDITOR
Busy Senior Steps Down as Head of The
News-Letter Along With Corner
and Catlin—Short Elected.

Alexander K. Barton, for three
Years one of the ablest editors of
-THE NEWS-LETTER, and editor-inchief since last June, resigned from
the position at the weekly meeting
of the Board Tuesday, because of
the press of other duties. J. Saulsbury Short, of the junior class, was
unanimously elected chief editor to
succeed Mr. Barton.
Harry Corner and Herbert Catlin, both members of the senior
class, tendered their resignations
along with Mr. Barton. Dorsey
Richardson, 'i6; Randolph Smith,
'17, and Fred P. Hall, '17, were
elected to the Board to fill the
places of the three editors who resigned. \V. A. McKewen,'17, was
elected an assistant business manager.
The list of candidates who had
been trying for the Board since the
beginning of the year was read,
and the editors selected the three
men whose work had been most
promising and voluminous. It was
ruled to hold all other candidates,
for more elections will be held before June, when the three remaining seniors on the Board resign.
This will probably be the most
important election in the next two
years, for there will not be such a
wholesale loss of men at the end
of next year because of the fact
that there is only one junior on the
Board at this time. This election
will probably take place just after
Easter.
At the meeting the Board decided
not to elect a man to the managing
editorship, but to assign the position monthly to a member of the
staff, so that every editor would
have some experience at collecting
copy, reading proof and makingup the paper. Each editor, according to his length of service as a
member of the Board, will act as
managing editor for four issues.
No member of the freshman class,
however, will be eligible for the
duty. C. J. Weber, '14, will be
managing editor for the next four
issues.
The resolution was offered by
Mr. Corner and adopted after some
discussion as to details. Members
of the Board realized the advantages of the new arrangement and
adopted it unanimously.

Mr. Martindale is one of Philadelphia's leading merchants and
citizens, and is an interesting writer
on outdoor sports. He is very
popular as a lecturer.
He is a very keen sportsman, and
his collection of trophies are noted
throughout the country. He has
camped and hunted extensively all
over the Maritime Provinces and
British Columbia territory, and a
year ago spent three months in the
Yukon region, hunting through
country probably never before
traveled by white man.
While there he secured a large
number of good pictures of interesting scenes and has put them
together in this popular lecture.
It is said to be vastly different
from the cut-and-dried travelogue,
since it is a recital of exciting incidents and personal experiences of
the trip.

Professor Adams Gives Excellent Discourse on British Feeling Toward
American Civil Conflict.

At the request of Dr. Charles
Francis Adams, Prof. Ephraim
Douglas Adamg", of Leland Stanford Jr. University, delivered last
Thursday the fifth of the Civil War
lectures, its specific topic being
"Some British Civil War Cartoons." The Boston historian believed that Professor Adams' illustrated lecture would throw more
light upon the English attitude in
the Civil War than he could in an
hour, and for this reason gave
way to the Western lecturer, whose
talk and slides were of great historical interest.
All the cartoons shown were
taken from the London Punch,
which was published weekly. This
comic has always endeavored to
express the real opinions of the
English people in political matters,
and its Civil War cartoons which
appeared in almost every issue
during the 1861-1865 period are
valuable expressions of British feeling.
Through the whole series of
drawings, it was plain that the
artist had a thorough understanding of the American conflict.
When the Federal Government
gave up Mason and Slidell, the
cartoonist saw the act as the result
of an English threat of war. A
clever drawing of Lincoln "up a
tree," in the shape of a coon, and
John Bull below him with a gun,
depicts the situation as seen by
British eyes.
The cartoonist began the series
by portraying Lincoln precisely as
he had found him in portraits.
Later, however, his drawings were,
as the lecturer said, made to make
Lincoln "silly and uncultured."
This interpretation of his character finally changed again, and as
the war was drawing to a close the
facial expression was made "brutal
and coarse." The final cartoon,
however, apologized for everything.
It was a drawing of Britannia placing garlands on the bier of the assassinated President.
Under that cartoon was a poem
of several verses by Toni Taylor,
apologizing for Punch's attitude.
Bales of cotton invariably formed
a background in the pictures.
"The cartoons," said Professor
Adams, "expressed the British
opinion on the Civil War. The
newspapers then were leaders in
thought, and the people believed in
the opinions they expressed. The
cartoons portray these opinions."
One of the cartoons depicted Lincoln as a bartender.
The South was depicted on April
15, 1865, as a gladiator with short
sword and shield, finally overcome
by the North, a gladiator with trident and net. The trident and net
signified that the North won by its
superiority at sea.

Engineers Meet March 2.

The next meeting of the Engineering Society will be held March
2, at five o'clock, in the physical
laboratory. Dr. Whitehead, professor of electrical engineering, will
describe two of the new nitrogenfilled Tungsten lamps which the
General Electric Company has recently put on the market.
Dr. Hurgronje's Lectures.

The two final lectures on Islam,
by Dr. C. Snouck Hurgronje, of
the University of Leyden, Holland,
were given Tuesday and Wednesday. Dr. Hurgronje is very well
versed in the religion of Islam, and
presented his discourses in an authoritative manner.
On Tuesday, the lecturer told of
the great regard held for the
prophet Mohammed, and of how
the Moslems still revel in the
prophecies that power and prestige
will come to Islam eventually.
The final lecture deliveded on
Wednesday treated the present day
conditions among the Moslems.
Dr. Hurgronje spoke of the
leniency of the divorce laws in
Islam, pointing out that the Moslem law, which no one dares repeal,
permits a man to have four wives.
Although poorly attended, Dr.
Hurgronje's last lecture was probably the most interesting .of the
series.

Cotillon Friday Night.

The second cotillon will be held
on Friday evening.
Special effort has been made by
the Cotillon Club t6 prolong the
time of the dance until at least
twelve-thirty, and the Board believes that Dean Griffin will comply with this request. If it is done,
the personnel of the musicians in
Fisher's orchestra, in order to have
some music, must be changed.
The Cotillon Club has worked
hard to make this second dance a
great success, and now it is "up
to" the students to encourage and
support their efforts.

BASEBALL PROSPECTS BRIGHT
Most of Last Year's Team Get on the Job
Again—Some Valuable Additions
Have Also Been Made.

The spirit shown so far among
the baseball men, and the fact that
nearly all of last year's men are
on their jobs again, as well as several new candidates of promise,
makes the prospects for a winning
team this year unusually bright.
About twenty-five men are reporting to the practices, held three times
a week for the present, on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday afternoons, and Captain Porter is working diligently to increase this number. A personal canvass of the students is being made, in an effort
to interest all former players. It
is believed that besides the several
new candidates who have already
come out there are others among
the nelk men who have had previous experience, and the effort is
being made to get all such men out
to the practices as soon as possible.
Among the new men who are already at work, Worthington, captain of the Princeton nine last season, is the most valuable addition.
He is a skillful infielder and is
thought to have his position at second cinched. However, he has
been giving valuable instruction to
several of the new men who aspire
to that important position, among
whom Victor Bridgeman is showing marked progress. The pitching staff has also been strengthened
by the addition of Gorman, from
City College, and Diefendorf, who
showed good form .at Central High
School of Washington last year,
and the catching department by the
appearance of Siebold. With Sylvester and Peiper back in the box,
and Rice Howell behind the bat,
the battery promises to hold up its
end of the team in fine form. Hobbs
is the most important loss_ from the
squad of last year. Bagley is making a strong bid for his position at
first base. Of course the practices
are very much restricted now by
the size of the cage, and Coach
Hooper is anxious to get the men
out to Homewood as soon as possible. The first game is scheduled
with Rock Hill College, Ellicott
City, Md., on March 22.
A game is under consideration
with Pennsylvania State University,
but Manager Hilgartner has not yet
been able to get the sanction of the
faculty, as it would have to be a
mid-week contest.
True Chivalry.

An old gentleman, always polite
to ladies, was asserting one day
that he had never seen a really ugly
woman. A woman with a flat nose,
overhearing him, said:
"Sir, look at me, and confess that
I'm truly ugly."
"Madam," he replied, "like the
rest of your sex, you are an angel
from the skies; but it was your
misfortune, rather than your fault,
that you happened to alight on your
nose."—Chronicle.

ST. JOHN'S HAZERS SUSPENDED

Dr. Buchner Tells the Maryland Institute
Alumni State Should Do More for
Its Young Men and Women.

Half of Sophomore Class Ordered From
Campus Indefinitely Because of
the Midnight Revelry.

Dr. Edward F. Buchner, professor of education, on whom the
trustees have placed the duty of
"going about and spreading the
gospel" concerning the Hopkins
"Tech," set forth the plans and
progress of the new department in
a well-received speech at the annual
banquet of the Maryland Institute
Alumni Association on Tuesday
night at the City Club.
Dr. Buchner advocated an educational survey of the State, expressing the opinion that Maryland should have a better knowledge of its educational resources
than it has at present. The State,
he thought, should do more towards instruct:ng its young men
and women just out of the elementary schools. He said that Maryland had partly accomplished this
in the provision for the new
"Tech," pointing out the fact that
almost half of the mo students
now enrolled in engineering courses
were residents of the counties.

Seventeen members of the sophomore class of St. John's College
were indefinitely suspended Friday
for engaging in hazing. The suspended boys were ordered to leave
the campus by two o'clock, Friday,
and they all obeyed.
The hazing took place at midnight about a week ago. The freshmen were routed out of their beds,
marched out to the athletic field in
their "nighties," and "put through
the stunts."
As soon as President Fell learned
of the hazing party, he ordered a
rigid investigation, and the result
was the suspension of half the
sophomore class. This action deals
a heavy blow to the basket11)0
team of the College.
The suspended men are: Heise,
Hauver, Selby, Cashell, Hyde, Miller, Jones, Miles, McKinley, Bielaski, Plummer, Andrew, Bowers,
Barley, Pearce, Welch and Hartsock.

For Editor Johns Hopkins Paper:

Dear Sir—Yesterday some men
from your college tried to steal our
family pet, a valuable and treasured
cat. This cat has been in our
family for over six years, coming
originally from Uraguay Nviith a
well established pedigree, and never
causing us the slightest worry.
Your men came along the back alley with a big potato bag and almost suffocated our Clementina in
carrying her to your workshop. 'I
went after her and finally rescued
her. I wish to state that I have
nothing to say against the gentlemen who met me at the door.
They were courteous, and promptly
saw that my cat was refunded. But
I want to object to such treatment
on the part of the ones who ran
off with the cat. It is a pity that
yotir college can't provide your
own cats to cut up and rip open
the way I saw them doing through
the window. Please don't try to
take our cat again. My little girl,
Marie, was almost driven to histerie
from fear for the cat. • Perhaps
you will not want to print this letter, but please do, or I will report
the matter to the S. P. C. A. SoYours truly,

The try-outs for the senior debating team were held Friday in
the Donovan Room, under the
supervision of Dr. French. After
giving all the contestants two or
three "hearings," he selected the
following men to represent the
seniors in the interclass debate on
Friday, March 13: Malcolm H.
I,auchheimer, chairman; Steuart D.
White, Carl J. Weber, A. K. Barton, alternate, and A. L. Hammond,
adviser.
Dr. French also announced that
F. C. Tarr had been selected as the
adviser of the junior team. The
time of the debate is only two weeks
from next Friday, and the debaters
have no time to lose. The subject
is "Resolved, That the Political Interests of the United States Demand the Abandonment of the
Monroe Doctrine."
The sophomore public speaking
contest will be held at the same
time as the debate. The preliminary trials were held Wednesday.
The following were chosen: R.
Webb-Peploe, T. J. Tingley and
L. C. Cohn.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 17.

PHYSICS KING AT THE '15 FEED
Dr. Ames'Popular Course Has Its Funny
Side—Freshmen Dine on Sly at
Maryland Country Club.

Physics was immortalized Mon(lay night at the junior class banquet at the Rennert.
Although there were only seven
set speeches, every member of the
class present "had something to
say.," and in respect to speech-making, the banquet was one of . the
most novel and interesting in the
history of Hopkins "feeds."
At the same time the juniors
were dining, sixty members of the
freshman class were sitting around
the board at the Maryland Country
Club. They had planned and carried off the affair in the utmost
secrecy, and for this reason were
able to spirit away the president of
the sophomore class, handcuffed
and in an automobile.
When his classmen learned of
this capture a handful rushed to
the club, but were not strong
enough in numbers to make any
concerted impression. One injured
freshman (black .eye), however,
was punished for his audacity, but
after a few minutes' chase over
the snowy fields in the vicinity of
the club, the sophomores got away.
The junior banquet was attended
by the spirits of W. H. Anderson
and "Billy" Sunday.
The menu was in the form of an
experiment, and the little book was
called "A Manual of Physics." The
cover, like the well known Ames
and Bliss volume, was of dark blue
.with printing in gold. A cut of the
Physics Laboratory adorned the
cover, and on the dome of the
building were the figures "1915,"
sending out rays of light in sunburst style.
The experiment, set in exact typographical imitation of its parent
volume, was:

EXPERIMENT I.
(A class of observers is required.)
Object: To verify Fletcher's theory
of mastication and to determine the coefficient of satisfaction at a class banquet.
General theory: Fletcher's theory of
mastication is derived from the f011owing hypotheses:
I. That food should be thoroughly
chewed.
2. That by chewing thoroughly,
greater nutriment may be derived from
the given amount of food.
3. That the amount of nutriment will
be directly proportional to the amount
of chewing.
From these rules Fletcher laid down
the formula:
Number of chews
= Nutriment.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 24, 1914.

DR. GOODNOW NEW HOPKINS PRESIDENT
Eton Professor of Political Science of Columbia University, and the
Present Constitutional Adviser to the Chinese Republic,
Chosen Six Weeks Ago—Official Announcement
at the Commemoration Day Exercises.
Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow, at
present the constitutional adviser to
the Chinese Republic, and one of
the foremost political scientists of
this country, will be the next president of the Johns Hopkins University.
The announcement that the Columbia University professor had
been selected by the trustees was
made yesterday by President Keyser, of the trustees, at the Commemoration Day exercises.
Dr. Goodnow succeeds Dr. Ira
Remsen, whose resignation from
the presidency was accepted on
April 21, 1911. In the interregnum
an administrative committee, headed by Dr. William H. Welch, had
acted as executive.
The selection of Dr. Goodnow
has delighted every friend of the
University. When the•trustees met
to consider the selection of a president, two alternatives were offered
which presented a difficult situation to solve. A man noted. for
scholarly attainments was desired
by some of :the trustees, while
others wanted a business man, one
whose chief service would be to collect funds and handle the details of
moving the University to its new
buildings on the Homewood estate.
After a consideration of the many
names, suggested, the trustees finally
agreed upon Dr. Goodnow as preeminently qualified to fill the presidency. He combined the two types
of man they were seeking. They
knew him to be one.of the foremost
of American educators, one of its
authorities on political science, and
he possessed eminent qualities of
business and organilation. For
these latter attributes he was selected to serve as adviser to the
new Chinese Republic.
The only obstacle that Stood in
the way of the Selection' of Dr.
Goodnow was the three-year contract he had made with China. This
did not balk the trustees, however,
for they had determined to secure
him. Dr. Goodnow was called, and
shortly after sent a reply :that he
would accept if he could be released
from his contract. The appearance
in Peking, China, of William W.
Rockhill, former American ambassador to Turkey, was followed immediately by the announcement that
President Yuan Shi-Kai of China
would gladly release Dr. Goodnow

The thirty-eighth anniversary of
the founding of Johns Hopkins,
celebrated Monday morning in McCoy Hall, was notable because of
the official announcement of the
selection of the University's third
president, Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow.
There, were, however, other features, which, had they not been overshadowed by the interest in R.
Brent Keyser's speech, would have
made the Commemoration Day exercises the most impressive in the
memory of present students of the
University.
Dr. Andrew Jackson Montague,
congressman from Virginia, and
former governor of his State, delivered a scholarly political oration
in which he said that President
Wilson owed his career to his Hopkins training.
A remarkably striking portrait of
Dean Edward H. Griffin, in academic gown, seated at his desk, was
presented to the University by the
Alumni Association.
W. Calvin Chesnut, a member of
the Baltimore bar, who was one of
the first to study under Dean Griffin when he came to Hopkins 25
years ago, delivered the presentation address.
Dr. Welch accepted the painting,
and looking around for Dean Griffin, finally located him in a corner
of the platform. The Dean arose in
response to the tribute that was
paid him, and the faculty and audience stood in his honor. The
portrait will be hung in McCoy'
Hall this week.

A. K. BARTON RESIGNS AS EDITOR
Busy Senior Steps Down as Head of The
News-Letter Along With Corner
and Catlin—Short Elected.

Alexander K. Barton, for three
Years one of the ablest editors of
-THE NEWS-LETTER, and editor-inchief since last June, resigned from
the position at the weekly meeting
of the Board Tuesday, because of
the press of other duties. J. Saulsbury Short, of the junior class, was
unanimously elected chief editor to
succeed Mr. Barton.
Harry Corner and Herbert Catlin, both members of the senior
class, tendered their resignations
along with Mr. Barton. Dorsey
Richardson, 'i6; Randolph Smith,
'17, and Fred P. Hall, '17, were
elected to the Board to fill the
places of the three editors who resigned. \V. A. McKewen,'17, was
elected an assistant business manager.
The list of candidates who had
been trying for the Board since the
beginning of the year was read,
and the editors selected the three
men whose work had been most
promising and voluminous. It was
ruled to hold all other candidates,
for more elections will be held before June, when the three remaining seniors on the Board resign.
This will probably be the most
important election in the next two
years, for there will not be such a
wholesale loss of men at the end
of next year because of the fact
that there is only one junior on the
Board at this time. This election
will probably take place just after
Easter.
At the meeting the Board decided
not to elect a man to the managing
editorship, but to assign the position monthly to a member of the
staff, so that every editor would
have some experience at collecting
copy, reading proof and makingup the paper. Each editor, according to his length of service as a
member of the Board, will act as
managing editor for four issues.
No member of the freshman class,
however, will be eligible for the
duty. C. J. Weber, '14, will be
managing editor for the next four
issues.
The resolution was offered by
Mr. Corner and adopted after some
discussion as to details. Members
of the Board realized the advantages of the new arrangement and
adopted it unanimously.

Professor Adams Gives Excellent Discourse on British Feeling Toward
American Civil Conflict.

At the request of Dr. Charles
Francis Adams, Prof. Ephraim
Douglas Adamg", of Leland Stanford Jr. University, delivered last
Thursday the fifth of the Civil War
lectures, its specific topic being
"Some British Civil War Cartoons." The Boston historian believed that Professor Adams' illustrated lecture would throw more
light upon the English attitude in
the Civil War than he could in an
hour, and for this reason gave
way to the Western lecturer, whose
talk and slides were of great historical interest.
All the cartoons shown were
taken from the London Punch,
which was published weekly. This
comic has always endeavored to
express the real opinions of the
English people in political matters,
and its Civil War cartoons which
appeared in almost every issue
during the 1861-1865 period are
valuable expressions of British feeling.
Through the whole series of
drawings, it was plain that the
artist had a thorough understanding of the American conflict.
When the Federal Government
gave up Mason and Slidell, the
cartoonist saw the act as the result
of an English threat of war. A
clever drawing of Lincoln "up a
tree," in the shape of a coon, and
John Bull below him with a gun,
depicts the situation as seen by
British eyes.
The cartoonist began the series
by portraying Lincoln precisely as
he had found him in portraits.
Later, however, his drawings were,
as the lecturer said, made to make
Lincoln "silly and uncultured."
This interpretation of his character finally changed again, and as
the war was drawing to a close the
facial expression was made "brutal
and coarse." The final cartoon,
however, apologized for everything.
It was a drawing of Britannia placing garlands on the bier of the assassinated President.
Under that cartoon was a poem
of several verses by Toni Taylor,
apologizing for Punch's attitude.
Bales of cotton invariably formed
a background in the pictures.
"The cartoons," said Professor
Adams, "expressed the British
opinion on the Civil War. The
newspapers then were leaders in
thought, and the people believed in
the opinions they expressed. The
cartoons portray these opinions."
One of the cartoons depicted Lincoln as a bartender.
The South was depicted on April
15, 1865, as a gladiator with short
sword and shield, finally overcome
by the North, a gladiator with trident and net. The trident and net
signified that the North won by its
superiority at sea.
The last of the war cartoons pictured two soldiers, one Southern

Dr. Hurgronje's Lectures.

The two final lectures on Islam,
by Dr. C. Snouck Hurgronje, of
the University of Leyden, Holland,
were given Tuesday and Wednesday. Dr. Hurgronje is very well
versed in the religion of Islam, and
presented his discourses in an authoritative manner.
On Tuesday, the lecturer told of
the great regard held for the
prophet Mohammed, and of how
the Moslems still revel in the
prophecies that power and prestige
will come to Islam eventually.
The final lecture deliveded on
Wednesday treated the present day
conditions among the Moslems.
Dr. Hurgronje spoke of the
leniency of the divorce laws in
Islam, pointing out that the Moslem law, which no one dares repeal,
permits a man to have four wives.
Although poorly attended, Dr.
Hurgronje's last lecture was probably the most interesting .of the
series.

BASEBALL PROSPECTS BRIGHT
Most of Last Year's Team Get on the Job
Again—Some Valuable Additions
Have Also Been Made.

The spirit shown so far among
the baseball men, and the fact that
nearly all of last year's men are
on their jobs again, as well as several new candidates of promise,
makes the prospects for a winning
team this year unusually bright.
About twenty-five men are reporting to the practices, held three times
a week for the present, on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday afternoons, and Captain Porter is working diligently to increase this number. A personal canvass of the students is being made, in an effort
to interest all former players. It
is believed that besides the several
new candidates who have already
come out there are others among
the nelk men who have had previous experience, and the effort is
being made to get all such men out
to the practices as soon as possible.
Among the new men who are already at work, Worthington, captain of the Princeton nine last season, is the most valuable addition.
He is a skillful infielder and is
thought to have his position at second cinched. However, he has
been giving valuable instruction to
several of the new men who aspire
to that important position, among
whom Victor Bridgeman is showing marked progress. The pitching staff has also been strengthened
by the addition of Gorman, from
City College, and Diefendorf, who
showed good form .at Central High
School of Washington last year,
and the catching department by the
appearance of Siebold. With Sylvester and Peiper back in the box,
and Rice Howell behind the bat,
the battery promises to hold up its
end of the team in fine form. Hobbs
is the most important loss_ from the
squad of last year. Bagley is making a strong bid for his position at
first base. Of course the practices
are very much restricted now by
the size of the cage, and Coach
Hooper is anxious to get the men
out to Homewood as soon as possible. The first game is scheduled
with Rock Hill College, Ellicott
City, Md., on March 22.
A game is under consideration
with Pennsylvania State University,
but Manager Hilgartner has not yet
been able to get the sanction of the
faculty, as it would have to be a
mid-week contest.
True Chivalry.

An old gentleman, always polite
to ladies, was asserting one day
that he had never seen a really ugly
woman. A woman with a flat nose,
overhearing him, said:
"Sir, look at me, and confess that
I'm truly ugly."
"Madam," he replied, "like the
rest of your sex, you are an angel
from the skies; but it was your
misfortune, rather than your fault,
that you happened to alight on your
nose."—Chronicle.

ST. JOHN'S HAZERS SUSPENDED

Dr. Buchner Tells the Maryland Institute
Alumni State Should Do More for
Its Young Men and Women.

Half of Sophomore Class Ordered From
Campus Indefinitely Because of
the Midnight Revelry.

Dr. Edward F. Buchner, professor of education, on whom the
trustees have placed the duty of
"going about and spreading the
gospel" concerning the Hopkins
"Tech," set forth the plans and
progress of the new department in
a well-received speech at the annual
banquet of the Maryland Institute
Alumni Association on Tuesday
night at the City Club.
Dr. Buchner advocated an educational survey of the State, expressing the opinion that Maryland should have a better knowledge of its educational resources
than it has at present. The State,
he thought, should do more towards instruct:ng its young men
and women just out of the elementary schools. He said that Maryland had partly accomplished this
in the provision for the new
"Tech," pointing out the fact that
almost half of the mo students
now enrolled in engineering courses
were residents of the counties.

Seventeen members of the sophomore class of St. John's College
were indefinitely suspended Friday
for engaging in hazing. The suspended boys were ordered to leave
the campus by two o'clock, Friday,
and they all obeyed.
The hazing took place at midnight about a week ago. The freshmen were routed out of their beds,
marched out to the athletic field in
their "nighties," and "put through
the stunts."
As soon as President Fell learned
of the hazing party, he ordered a
rigid investigation, and the result
was the suspension of half the
sophomore class. This action deals
a heavy blow to the basket11)0
team of the College.
The suspended men are: Heise,
Hauver, Selby, Cashell, Hyde, Miller, Jones, Miles, McKinley, Bielaski, Plummer, Andrew, Bowers,
Barley, Pearce, Welch and Hartsock.

HUGO.

We Advise Securing Seats Well in Advance.

CARLETON'S

FOR WIDER STATE INTEREST

For Editor Johns Hopkins Paper:

Dear Sir—Yesterday some men
from your college tried to steal our
family pet, a valuable and treasured
cat. This cat has been in our
family for over six years, coming
originally from Uraguay Nviith a
well established pedigree, and never
causing us the slightest worry.
Your men came along the back alley with a big potato bag and almost suffocated our Clementina in
carrying her to your workshop. 'I
went after her and finally rescued
her. I wish to state that I have
nothing to say against the gentlemen who met me at the door.
They were courteous, and promptly
saw that my cat was refunded. But
I want to object to such treatment
on the part of the ones who ran

SENIOR DEBATING TEAM CHOSEN

THE BOSTON "TECH" GIGANTIC

Lauchheimer, White and Weber to Uphold Senior's Cause in Interclass
Debate Sophs Chosen.

$7,000,000 in Special Gifts Makes Possible Esta lishment of New "White
City" on the Charles.

The try-outs for the senior debating team were held Friday in
the Donovan Room, under the
supervision of Dr. French. After
giving all the contestants two or
three "hearings," he selected the
following men to represent the
seniors in the interclass debate on
Friday, March 13: Malcolm H.
I,auchheimer, chairman; Steuart D.
White, Carl J. Weber, A. K. Barton, alternate, and A. L. Hammond,
adviser.
Dr. French also announced that
F. C. Tarr had been selected as the
adviser of the junior team. The
time of the debate is only two weeks
from next Friday, and the debaters
have no time to lose. The subject
is "Resolved, That the Political Interests of the United States Demand the Abandonment of the
Monroe Doctrine."
The sophomore public speaking
contest will be held at the same
time as the debate. The preliminary trials were held Wednesday.
The following were chosen: R.
Webb-Peploe, T. J. Tingley and
L. C. Cohn.
